scenes.background: You are on annual leave, enjoying some well-deserved time off to recharge. However, during your time away, a colleague messages you privately, saying there’s an urgent task that needs immediate attention. The request creates a dilemma as you try to balance respecting your time off while feeling the pressure to help with the urgent task. You chose to take a quick look and help out. After some time, [Monica] and [Bob] approach you in the cafeteria. [Monica] looks slightly concerned while [Bob] seems indifferent. You expressed understanding of Monica's concerns and acknowledged you should have set clearer boundaries. [Bob] then chimed in, and you emphasized the need for balance. [Monica] sighed and shared her frustration about people not respecting time off, to which you acknowledged the complexity of the situation.
scenes.description: [Bob] then says, 'Well, if we start setting too many rules, we might just end up making things more complicated. What do you think, [Alex]?'

options.text: It's possible, but maybe some structure could actually make things simpler.
options.analysis: You offer a balanced perspective, showing good self-regulation and social skills while acknowledging the potential benefits of structure.

options.text: You might be right, Bob. Too many rules could backfire.
options.analysis: You agree with Bob's point, showing strong empathy and emotional perception but lower social skills.

options.text: If we don’t set any rules, we might end up in chaos. Boundaries are necessary.
options.analysis: You take a more assertive stance, showing strong motivation but lower empathy and social skills.
